Premier League: 10 talking points from the weekend’s action
===========================================================

Amad Diallo shows versatility, Ethan Nwaneri offers plenty of potential and Danny Welbeck’s role is key for Brighton

* * *

1

Diallo thrives in unfamiliar role
---------------------------------

For the established full-back, a wing-back role must be liberating, permission granted to embark on an adventure in the other half. Amad Diallo was faced with the less desirable situation against Ipswich, a forward forced to track back as he slotted in on the right of Ruben Amorim’s 3-4-2-1. Diallo retained his attacking aggression, immediately rampaging forward and evading challenges to set up Marcus Rashford’s early opener. He was responsible in defence and one of United’s brightest performers in a mostly bleak display, even threatening to deliver a late winner when cutting inside into the box to let fly. Diallo is most likely just a stopgap in the position but his adaptability has some worth as Amorim searches for his best XI. **Taha Hashim**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Ipswich 1-1 Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

2

Delap shows stomach for Ipswich’s fight
---------------------------------------

Towards the end of the first half against [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united), Ipswich’s Liam Delap opted for the unnecessary. With the ball travelling out for a throw, the forward charged into Noussair Mazraoui, prompting a square up between the two. Delap was fortunate to avoid a yellow but his need for a scrap is what makes him a player. He hassled United when dropping deep, using his flicks and dinks to muster space and drive into the box. His evening was ruined, though, by André Onana, who saved twice from close range – the first a stunner with an outstretched right arm – denying Delap from improving an already impressive goalscoring record in the Premier League. The 21-year-old has acquired seven yellows this season for his club and England Under-21s. He plays on the edge but hasn’t tripped up just yet. **TH**

* * *

3

Spurs should follow Kulusevski’s lead
-------------------------------------

At 24, and five years into his senior career, Dejan Kulusevski has no doubt where Tottenham’s [scintillating performance at Manchester City](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/manchester-city-tottenham-premier-league-match-report) ranks. “I’d say it’s the best result ever in my career, it’s a big night for the whole club, for the coach \[Ange Postecoglou\], for the players but it’s not a turning point,” said the forward. “We have to be better in other games.” The Swede, who impressed throughout, was also bullish about his own abilities. “I have something that no other player has. So you can’t compare me to any other player – this is what I’m looking for. Of course, I watch other players. I take the best stuff from them, but with my engine, you know, with my heart – I don’t get tired – I feel like I can still do a lot in my career. I can’t let anybody outwork me. That’s the plan. That’s how I play and how I train.” **Jamie Jackson**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Manchester City 0-4 Tottenham](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/manchester-city-tottenham-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

4

Hope for Saints in latest loss
------------------------------

Southampton had only six shots against Liverpool – they have managed more than that in 11 of their 14 previous games in all competitions this season, and at least doubled that number on five occasions. As they continue to play themselves into trouble at the back and remain marooned at the bottom of the table there are not many straws around for them to clutch, but if they could discover a clinical touch it would certainly help. “What was a bit unlucky for them I think is normally they play much better and create much more chances and hardly score,” Arne Slot said. “Today they created few chances and scored two. If they combine these things, so the style of play they had in other games with the effectiveness they had today, then I’m sure they will win some games.” As his team had just demonstrated, if a team can play quite poorly and still score a few goals, they just might be on to something. **Simon Burnton**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Southampton 2-3 Liverpool](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/southampton-liverpool-premier-league-match-report)_
    

![Image 7: Liverpool’s Andrew Robertson holds the shirt of Southampton’s Tyler Dibling.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/13a95aea34f8c943e51b3e6f217ea5c48b4a9d5c/0_332_5641_3385/master/5641.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/25/premier-league-10-talking-points-from-the-weekend-action#img-2)

Liverpool’s Andrew Robertson holds the shirt of Southampton’s Tyler Dibling. Photograph: Sean Ryan/AP

* * *

5

Nwaneri offers vital new Arsenal option
---------------------------------------

Every week, it feels, brings a new landmark for Ethan Nwaneri. When he was 15 years and 181 days old, he became the youngest player ever to play in the English top flight. On 25 September this year, at the grand old age of 17, he got his first senior goals, scoring twice in a Carabao Cup win over Bolton. And on Saturday, he sidefooted home Raheem Sterling’s low cross to wrap up [Arsenal’s 3-0 win over Nottingham Forest](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/arsenal-nottingham-forest-premier-league-match-report); Cesc Fàbregas is Arsenal’s only younger league scorer. He’d been on the field less than two minutes, yet already his energy and invention had enlivened a game that was drifting towards its conclusion. Whether he’s at his best wide or through the middle remains to be seen, but Nwaneri is clearly a player of enormous gifts. Arsenal, after years of slightly uninspiring back-up options off the bench, suddenly have a forward of genuinely thrilling potential. **Jonathan Wilson**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Arsenal 3-0 Nottingham Forest](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/arsenal-nottingham-forest-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

6

Targeted Palmer needs protection
--------------------------------

If you can’t beat him, kick him. Cole Palmer is now a target for opposition players. Lisandro Martínez took him out during Chelsea’s draw with Manchester United early this month and there was more rough treatment from Leicester’s Wilfred Ndidi on Saturday. It was cynical from Ndidi, who showed no regard for a fellow professional when he raked his studs down Palmer’s achilles. The [Chelsea](https://www.theguardian.com/football/chelsea) playmaker easily could have been injured. He stayed down for a while and there was an argument that Ndidi should have been sent off. The Leicester midfielder only saw yellow, though, and there has to be a valid concern over whether Palmer needs more protection from referees. Chelsea experienced similar with Eden Hazard, who often came in for heavy challenges from opposition defenders desperate to slow him down. The dangers are clear. Martínez and Ndidi both escaped red cards but at some point one of the best attackers in England is going to get hurt. **Jacob Steinberg**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Leicester 1-2 Chelsea](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/leicester-chelsea-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

7

Lemina helps sweep Wolves to victory
------------------------------------

Necessity – an injury crisis within a relegation battle – bred invention [for Wolves at Fulham](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/fulham-wolves-premier-league-match-report). If Matheus Cunha’s contribution of two spectacular goals and a fine assist for João Gomes deservedly took the spotlight, then Wolves’ captain, Mario Lemina, showed leadership and adaptability in a cut-and-shut defensive trio. Rayan Aït-Nouri, better known for his attacking qualities, was another of the three, and threw in some vital interventions, almost scoring an own goal in doing so. Lemina, meanwhile, produced a throwback display to remind of sweepers of days gone by controlling the game from deep and supplying Cunha’s first, an equaliser at an important juncture, with a laser-guided diagonal to the Brazilian. Freeform improvisation? Not according to Gary O’Neil. “Straight off the training ground,” explained a manager safer after two successive wins and clearly confident in his own abilities. “Matheus would never arrive in that spot, if we haven’t practised that for the last few months.” **John Brewin**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Fulham 1-4 Wolves](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/fulham-wolves-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

8

Devenny chalks one up for patience
----------------------------------

Beyond Crystal Palace, Justin Devenny was a relative unknown until this month. The 21-year-old scored his first goal for the club in his second appearance, [against Villa on Saturday](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/aston-villa-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report). His route to the Premier League has not been the usual story of constant upward trajectory; the midfielder started his career at Kilmarnock but they allowed him to leave for Airdrieonians in the Scottish Championship, where he was spotted by Palace and brought south. Often people expect to have their breakthrough as a teenager, but Devenny has shown that patience is beneficial even for an aspirational young player. He was disciplined and effective against Villa, with his goal capping off a fine week in which he made his Northern Ireland debut. “He was with us in the pre-season in the USA, and he showed he’s an unbelievable footballer, very technical, he can also run a lot,” said the Palace manager, Oliver Glasner. “He can play in four positions, he understands the game, he finds the space, and he also can score goals, and this is what he showed – we were very confident in him.” **Will Unwin**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Aston Villa 2-2 Crystal Palace](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/aston-villa-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report)_

Justin Devenny shoots past Youri Tielemans to score Crystal Palace’s second goal at Aston Villa. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters

* * *

9

Welbeck plays provider and leader
---------------------------------

After six goals in his first nine league games, Danny Welbeck has quietened down in recent weeks, with João Pedro returning from injury to resume his position as Brighton’s main attacking force. Welbeck’s influence remains, his hold-up play outside the area teeing up [two goals against Bournemouth](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/bournemouth-brighton-premier-league-match-report), the captain’s armband on as he leads in the absence of the injured Lewis Dunk. Under Fabian Hürzeler, two years his junior, Welbeck has started every league game this season, which must provide great joy considering the injuries he encountered at Arsenal. A while back, his narrative was of a gifted forward tied up in misfortune, a career that took in trophies and major tournaments but never really advanced past his early-to-mid-20s. Now the central theme is his role as a been-there-done-that battler for Brighton, a key man in their establishment as Premier League mainstays. **TH**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Bournemouth 1-2 Brighton](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/bournemouth-brighton-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

10

Blunt Everton need attacking urgency
------------------------------------

After [a third match without a goal](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/everton-brentford-premier-league-match-report), and this time having played for 53 minutes against 10 men, Sean Dyche was asked whether he needed to work more on Everton’s attacking game. The question was not impertinent. It was, worryingly for the manager, a perfectly reasonable conclusion to draw from his team’s stagnant efforts against a Brentford side that had not kept a clean sheet or gained an away point all season before arriving at Goodison Park. “We’ve been working endlessly since I’ve been here to attack better,” Dyche replied with a touch of incredulity. “We have got very good players here and it is my responsibility to make them better or, if I can’t make them better, make them as a unit win.” The problem for Dyche – aside from the league table, a daunting December fixture list and the prospect of working for new owners – is that individuals are not improving and the collective is not winning. And Everton never looked like winning against Thomas Frank’s 10 men. More work is required to end the status quo. **Andy Hunter**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Everton 0-0 Brentford](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/everton-brentford-premier-league-match-report)_

### Guardian Pick

Once again, we see predictions are pointless.

Man City will bounce back against Spurs?

Liverpool will give Southampton a shellacking?

Amorim will get Utd playing exciting football again?

There have probably been weeks when pundits have been more wrong, but I struggle to think of an example.

Premier League: 10 talking points from the weekend’s action
===========================================================

Amad Diallo shows versatility, Ethan Nwaneri offers plenty of potential and Danny Welbeck’s role is key for Brighton

* * *

1

Diallo thrives in unfamiliar role
---------------------------------

For the established full-back, a wing-back role must be liberating, permission granted to embark on an adventure in the other half. Amad Diallo was faced with the less desirable situation against Ipswich, a forward forced to track back as he slotted in on the right of Ruben Amorim’s 3-4-2-1. Diallo retained his attacking aggression, immediately rampaging forward and evading challenges to set up Marcus Rashford’s early opener. He was responsible in defence and one of United’s brightest performers in a mostly bleak display, even threatening to deliver a late winner when cutting inside into the box to let fly. Diallo is most likely just a stopgap in the position but his adaptability has some worth as Amorim searches for his best XI. **Taha Hashim**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Ipswich 1-1 Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

2

Delap shows stomach for Ipswich’s fight
---------------------------------------

Towards the end of the first half against [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united), Ipswich’s Liam Delap opted for the unnecessary. With the ball travelling out for a throw, the forward charged into Noussair Mazraoui, prompting a square up between the two. Delap was fortunate to avoid a yellow but his need for a scrap is what makes him a player. He hassled United when dropping deep, using his flicks and dinks to muster space and drive into the box. His evening was ruined, though, by André Onana, who saved twice from close range – the first a stunner with an outstretched right arm – denying Delap from improving an already impressive goalscoring record in the Premier League. The 21-year-old has acquired seven yellows this season for his club and England Under-21s. He plays on the edge but hasn’t tripped up just yet. **TH**

* * *

3

Spurs should follow Kulusevski’s lead
-------------------------------------

At 24, and five years into his senior career, Dejan Kulusevski has no doubt where Tottenham’s [scintillating performance at Manchester City](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/manchester-city-tottenham-premier-league-match-report) ranks. “I’d say it’s the best result ever in my career, it’s a big night for the whole club, for the coach \[Ange Postecoglou\], for the players but it’s not a turning point,” said the forward. “We have to be better in other games.” The Swede, who impressed throughout, was also bullish about his own abilities. “I have something that no other player has. So you can’t compare me to any other player – this is what I’m looking for. Of course, I watch other players. I take the best stuff from them, but with my engine, you know, with my heart – I don’t get tired – I feel like I can still do a lot in my career. I can’t let anybody outwork me. That’s the plan. That’s how I play and how I train.” **Jamie Jackson**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Manchester City 0-4 Tottenham](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/manchester-city-tottenham-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

4

Hope for Saints in latest loss
------------------------------

Southampton had only six shots against Liverpool – they have managed more than that in 11 of their 14 previous games in all competitions this season, and at least doubled that number on five occasions. As they continue to play themselves into trouble at the back and remain marooned at the bottom of the table there are not many straws around for them to clutch, but if they could discover a clinical touch it would certainly help. “What was a bit unlucky for them I think is normally they play much better and create much more chances and hardly score,” Arne Slot said. “Today they created few chances and scored two. If they combine these things, so the style of play they had in other games with the effectiveness they had today, then I’m sure they will win some games.” As his team had just demonstrated, if a team can play quite poorly and still score a few goals, they just might be on to something. **Simon Burnton**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Southampton 2-3 Liverpool](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/southampton-liverpool-premier-league-match-report)_
    

![Image 7: Liverpool’s Andrew Robertson holds the shirt of Southampton’s Tyler Dibling.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/13a95aea34f8c943e51b3e6f217ea5c48b4a9d5c/0_332_5641_3385/master/5641.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/25/premier-league-10-talking-points-from-the-weekend-action#img-2)

Liverpool’s Andrew Robertson holds the shirt of Southampton’s Tyler Dibling. Photograph: Sean Ryan/AP

* * *

5

Nwaneri offers vital new Arsenal option
---------------------------------------

Every week, it feels, brings a new landmark for Ethan Nwaneri. When he was 15 years and 181 days old, he became the youngest player ever to play in the English top flight. On 25 September this year, at the grand old age of 17, he got his first senior goals, scoring twice in a Carabao Cup win over Bolton. And on Saturday, he sidefooted home Raheem Sterling’s low cross to wrap up [Arsenal’s 3-0 win over Nottingham Forest](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/arsenal-nottingham-forest-premier-league-match-report); Cesc Fàbregas is Arsenal’s only younger league scorer. He’d been on the field less than two minutes, yet already his energy and invention had enlivened a game that was drifting towards its conclusion. Whether he’s at his best wide or through the middle remains to be seen, but Nwaneri is clearly a player of enormous gifts. Arsenal, after years of slightly uninspiring back-up options off the bench, suddenly have a forward of genuinely thrilling potential. **Jonathan Wilson**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Arsenal 3-0 Nottingham Forest](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/arsenal-nottingham-forest-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

6

Targeted Palmer needs protection
--------------------------------

If you can’t beat him, kick him. Cole Palmer is now a target for opposition players. Lisandro Martínez took him out during Chelsea’s draw with Manchester United early this month and there was more rough treatment from Leicester’s Wilfred Ndidi on Saturday. It was cynical from Ndidi, who showed no regard for a fellow professional when he raked his studs down Palmer’s achilles. The [Chelsea](https://www.theguardian.com/football/chelsea) playmaker easily could have been injured. He stayed down for a while and there was an argument that Ndidi should have been sent off. The Leicester midfielder only saw yellow, though, and there has to be a valid concern over whether Palmer needs more protection from referees. Chelsea experienced similar with Eden Hazard, who often came in for heavy challenges from opposition defenders desperate to slow him down. The dangers are clear. Martínez and Ndidi both escaped red cards but at some point one of the best attackers in England is going to get hurt. **Jacob Steinberg**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Leicester 1-2 Chelsea](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/leicester-chelsea-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

7

Lemina helps sweep Wolves to victory
------------------------------------

Necessity – an injury crisis within a relegation battle – bred invention [for Wolves at Fulham](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/fulham-wolves-premier-league-match-report). If Matheus Cunha’s contribution of two spectacular goals and a fine assist for João Gomes deservedly took the spotlight, then Wolves’ captain, Mario Lemina, showed leadership and adaptability in a cut-and-shut defensive trio. Rayan Aït-Nouri, better known for his attacking qualities, was another of the three, and threw in some vital interventions, almost scoring an own goal in doing so. Lemina, meanwhile, produced a throwback display to remind of sweepers of days gone by controlling the game from deep and supplying Cunha’s first, an equaliser at an important juncture, with a laser-guided diagonal to the Brazilian. Freeform improvisation? Not according to Gary O’Neil. “Straight off the training ground,” explained a manager safer after two successive wins and clearly confident in his own abilities. “Matheus would never arrive in that spot, if we haven’t practised that for the last few months.” **John Brewin**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Fulham 1-4 Wolves](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/fulham-wolves-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

8

Devenny chalks one up for patience
----------------------------------

Beyond Crystal Palace, Justin Devenny was a relative unknown until this month. The 21-year-old scored his first goal for the club in his second appearance, [against Villa on Saturday](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/aston-villa-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report). His route to the Premier League has not been the usual story of constant upward trajectory; the midfielder started his career at Kilmarnock but they allowed him to leave for Airdrieonians in the Scottish Championship, where he was spotted by Palace and brought south. Often people expect to have their breakthrough as a teenager, but Devenny has shown that patience is beneficial even for an aspirational young player. He was disciplined and effective against Villa, with his goal capping off a fine week in which he made his Northern Ireland debut. “He was with us in the pre-season in the USA, and he showed he’s an unbelievable footballer, very technical, he can also run a lot,” said the Palace manager, Oliver Glasner. “He can play in four positions, he understands the game, he finds the space, and he also can score goals, and this is what he showed – we were very confident in him.” **Will Unwin**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Aston Villa 2-2 Crystal Palace](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/aston-villa-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report)_
    

![Image 8: Justin Devenny shoots past Youri Tielemans to score Crystal Palace’s second goal at Aston Villa.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/d940e8809ad76a471a6998f9dc7e24b899d2a6d1/0_108_2975_1785/master/2975.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/25/premier-league-10-talking-points-from-the-weekend-action#img-3)

Justin Devenny shoots past Youri Tielemans to score Crystal Palace’s second goal at Aston Villa. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters

* * *

9

Welbeck plays provider and leader
---------------------------------

After six goals in his first nine league games, Danny Welbeck has quietened down in recent weeks, with João Pedro returning from injury to resume his position as Brighton’s main attacking force. Welbeck’s influence remains, his hold-up play outside the area teeing up [two goals against Bournemouth](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/bournemouth-brighton-premier-league-match-report), the captain’s armband on as he leads in the absence of the injured Lewis Dunk. Under Fabian Hürzeler, two years his junior, Welbeck has started every league game this season, which must provide great joy considering the injuries he encountered at Arsenal. A while back, his narrative was of a gifted forward tied up in misfortune, a career that took in trophies and major tournaments but never really advanced past his early-to-mid-20s. Now the central theme is his role as a been-there-done-that battler for Brighton, a key man in their establishment as Premier League mainstays. **TH**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Bournemouth 1-2 Brighton](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/bournemouth-brighton-premier-league-match-report)_
    

* * *

10

Blunt Everton need attacking urgency
------------------------------------

After [a third match without a goal](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/everton-brentford-premier-league-match-report), and this time having played for 53 minutes against 10 men, Sean Dyche was asked whether he needed to work more on Everton’s attacking game. The question was not impertinent. It was, worryingly for the manager, a perfectly reasonable conclusion to draw from his team’s stagnant efforts against a Brentford side that had not kept a clean sheet or gained an away point all season before arriving at Goodison Park. “We’ve been working endlessly since I’ve been here to attack better,” Dyche replied with a touch of incredulity. “We have got very good players here and it is my responsibility to make them better or, if I can’t make them better, make them as a unit win.” The problem for Dyche – aside from the league table, a daunting December fixture list and the prospect of working for new owners – is that individuals are not improving and the collective is not winning. And Everton never looked like winning against Thomas Frank’s 10 men. More work is required to end the status quo. **Andy Hunter**

* * *

*   _Match report: [Everton 0-0 Brentford](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/everton-brentford-premier-league-match-report)_

**Subscribe to Soccer with Jonathan Wilson, a weekly newsletter from one of the world’s top soccer journalists.**

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Jonathan Wilson

### Guardian Pick

The point about protecting Palmer (and others) from on-field violence is well made but there persists an uneasy attitude towards how we differentiate violence from 'hardness', often glorifying the latter and celebrating certain hardmen.  
How many times have we watched a young exciting player, new to the Premier League, take a potentially career ending tackle early on, while the commentator joyously shouts 'Oof, Welcome to the Premiership!', …

There have probably been weeks when pundits have been more wrong, but I struggle to think of an example.

=============== 

[Skip to main content](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#maincontent)[Skip to navigation](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#navigation)[Skip to navigation](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#navigation)

![Image 2: Manchester United’s Noussair Mazraoui, Bruno Fernandes and Christian Eriksen look dejected after Ipswich’s equaliser.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/1fca2f5e42b8dc862d35b3a7ad29ea77660df3b6/187_218_4320_2592/master/4320.jpg?width=465&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)

Manchester United’s Noussair Mazraoui, Bruno Fernandes and Christian Eriksen look dejected after Ipswich’s equaliser. Photograph: Tom Jenkins/The Guardian

[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#img-1)

Manchester United’s Noussair Mazraoui, Bruno Fernandes and Christian Eriksen look dejected after Ipswich’s equaliser. Photograph: Tom Jenkins/The Guardian

[Analysis](https://www.theguardian.com/tone/analysis)

Manchester United’s joyless incoherence frees Amorim from any illusions
=======================================================================

[Barney Ronay](https://www.theguardian.com/profile/barneyronay) at Portman Road

Digesting the deathly spirit of this team in the flesh will have emphasised to the coach the complexities of his task

Well, something to work on there then, Ruben. It would be tempting at the end of [this decelerating game of semi-football](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report) to talk about Ruben Amorim at least _realising the scale of the job_ he faces.

Except, given Amorim almost certainly possesses a TV set and is interested in football, he already knows the scale of the job. And the scale is: really very big indeed.

It’s not the scale though. It’s the tone, the texture, the deathly spirit of this United team that really needs to be digested in the flesh, the sheer joyless incoherence, a [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united) team that is all trapped energy and broken patterns, the football equivalent of a chipped gravy boat handed down unhappily through the generations.

[Ruben Amorim says Manchester United will ‘suffer’ after fast start fizzles out Read more](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ruben-amorim-says-manchester-united-will-suffer-after-fast-start-fizzles-out)

It was there in the hilariously ambling patterns of Joshua Zirkzee, who just seems always to be floating around quite close to the spectacle, like a man listening to a podcast while strolling on the local rec, tactfully avoiding the dogwalkers.

It was there in a fascinating interlude on 24 minutes as United ferried the ball around sleepily, the backline completely failing to intersect with the midfield in front of it, no angles, no pockets to shift past the press. Watching this, Amorim looked calm, poker faced, right up to the moment you looked at his feet and he seemed to be trying to stand on tip toes, doing some kind of secretive hyper-clenched thigh workout, swallowing it down. He spread his arms wide as another pass shuttled across the face of the penalty area, possession without hunger or drive or purpose, football happening in a vacuum.

Quick Guide

#### Keane clashes with Ipswich fan

Show

Roy Keane became embroiled in an angry exchange with an Ipswich fan on Sunday. While off air for Sky Sports’ punditry team on the Portman Road pitch, Keane came in for abuse from a supporter who barracked him as ‘a better pundit than manager’. Keane, who was Ipswich manager from 2009 to 2011, stormed over to the fan in the stands and repeatedly shouted that they should ‘discuss it in the car park’.

With this in mind, for United’s fans the most heartening aspect of this deathly 1-1 draw with Ipswich is that Amorim very clearly gets this. “We are going to suffer for a long period,” he shrugged, smiling just a little bit wearily in his post-match press conference at Portman Road. The job is huge, overwhelming, perhaps even insoluble. The first positive step is knowing all these things for certain. And Amorim’s players did him a favour in that respect here. He is, if nothing else, utterly free from any kind of illusions.

From the start there was something lovely and windswept and vaguely Jane Austen about travelling through the Suffolk countryside to meet a handsome man with brooding eyes who has been charged with reviving a grand old ailing estate.

The three-week hiatus between appointment and full match-day rein-taking had given this occasion a sense of delayed intrigue, nine days of intense tactical edging about wing-backs and centre-half partnerships.

![Image 3: 'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/7ec06c479b841a74129e684ca3998dbf4768effa/0_0_1843_1037/1843.jpg?width=465&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)

2:11

'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video

There was a slight sense of double take about Amorim’s starting XI . OK. So, we’re going new energy, freshness, unforgiving demands on press and movement and structure. We’re going – it says here - with Casemiro, Christian Eriksen and Jonny Evans.

But it only took 82 seconds for everything to be all right, with a goal that came entirely from the Amorim rejig. Amad Diallo at right wing-back? Yep. We can do that too. Here he took the ball close to halfway and went straight into a full, ravenous, high rev sprint. The low cross with his newly empowered right foot was perfectly measured. Marcus Rashford just had to walk the ball into the net.

[skip past newsletter promotion](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#EmailSignup-skip-link-13)after newsletter promotion

[Amorim’s Manchester United pegged back by Ipswich after rapid start Read more](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)

Amorim’s reaction was perfect, in that there was no reaction, just a swivel back towards the bench, a flicker perhaps in the eyes. Rashford seemed out of sorts in those early moments. That is, he seemed hungry, energised and furiously mobile. He sprinted after lost passes, fouled and harried.

And for a while, as United had their best spell, there was a chance to linger on that vital quality, the Amorim touchline energy. There was an aura from the start, striding out in heavy-tog quilted coat, white trainers, skinny tailored slacks, off-the-peg Euro football royalty uniform. The package is good.

Jawline, hair, the controlled energy in his movements.

The United away support, which is always noisy, got to roll around and bounce and sing about the 12 Cantonas of Christmas. It didn’t last. Ipswich pressed back with real purpose, a process that is always easier when you find no resistance, a gap, a space to press into.

United’s midfield structure was odd, porous, leaving pathways that Ipswich began to trace, moving in neat triangles between the static parts. The equaliser was always coming, and it was fitting Omari Hutchison should score it after a sublime, high-craft first half.

Either side André Onana produced not one but two astonishing point-blank saves from Liam Delap. Delap is a wonderful spectacle in the flesh, a huge, thick barrelling figure, charging about as though he’s barely in control of his own gravity, a man always chasing a round of cheese down a Gloucestershire hillside. He really should have decided this game.

Amorim didn’t sit down through all of this. He didn’t scream and shout and point. Instead he paced, hands bunched in his pockets, in an ever shrinking arc from left to right. Somebody needs to take a cleaver to this thing. Amorim may have a kind of Left Bank soulfulness about him, soft deep brown eyes, the perfectly cropped bristles. But he is also clear-eyed and ruthless. And yes, he really is going to need all of that.

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Manchester United’s joyless incoherence frees Amorim from any illusions
=======================================================================

[Barney Ronay](https://www.theguardian.com/profile/barneyronay) at Portman Road

Digesting the deathly spirit of this team in the flesh will have emphasised to the coach the complexities of his task

Well, something to work on there then, Ruben. It would be tempting at the end of [this decelerating game of semi-football](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report) to talk about Ruben Amorim at least _realising the scale of the job_ he faces.

Except, given Amorim almost certainly possesses a TV set and is interested in football, he already knows the scale of the job. And the scale is: really very big indeed.

It’s not the scale though. It’s the tone, the texture, the deathly spirit of this United team that really needs to be digested in the flesh, the sheer joyless incoherence, a [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united) team that is all trapped energy and broken patterns, the football equivalent of a chipped gravy boat handed down unhappily through the generations.

[![Image 7: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim applauds the travelling support with his players at Portman Road.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/aad0f0c7066cebe7ebc1cd60e5bbcb99b6a88433/0_29_6000_3600/master/6000.jpg?width=460&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=2100854616a302979aa1425592f34bfc) Ruben Amorim says Manchester United will ‘suffer’ after fast start fizzles out Read more](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ruben-amorim-says-manchester-united-will-suffer-after-fast-start-fizzles-out)

It was there in the hilariously ambling patterns of Joshua Zirkzee, who just seems always to be floating around quite close to the spectacle, like a man listening to a podcast while strolling on the local rec, tactfully avoiding the dogwalkers.

It was there in a fascinating interlude on 24 minutes as United ferried the ball around sleepily, the backline completely failing to intersect with the midfield in front of it, no angles, no pockets to shift past the press. Watching this, Amorim looked calm, poker faced, right up to the moment you looked at his feet and he seemed to be trying to stand on tip toes, doing some kind of secretive hyper-clenched thigh workout, swallowing it down. He spread his arms wide as another pass shuttled across the face of the penalty area, possession without hunger or drive or purpose, football happening in a vacuum.

Quick Guide

#### Keane clashes with Ipswich fan

Show

Roy Keane became embroiled in an angry exchange with an Ipswich fan on Sunday. While off air for Sky Sports’ punditry team on the Portman Road pitch, Keane came in for abuse from a supporter who barracked him as ‘a better pundit than manager’. Keane, who was Ipswich manager from 2009 to 2011, stormed over to the fan in the stands and repeatedly shouted that they should ‘discuss it in the car park’.

With this in mind, for United’s fans the most heartening aspect of this deathly 1-1 draw with Ipswich is that Amorim very clearly gets this. “We are going to suffer for a long period,” he shrugged, smiling just a little bit wearily in his post-match press conference at Portman Road. The job is huge, overwhelming, perhaps even insoluble. The first positive step is knowing all these things for certain. And Amorim’s players did him a favour in that respect here. He is, if nothing else, utterly free from any kind of illusions.

From the start there was something lovely and windswept and vaguely Jane Austen about travelling through the Suffolk countryside to meet a handsome man with brooding eyes who has been charged with reviving a grand old ailing estate.

The three-week hiatus between appointment and full match-day rein-taking had given this occasion a sense of delayed intrigue, nine days of intense tactical edging about wing-backs and centre-half partnerships.

![Image 8: 'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/7ec06c479b841a74129e684ca3998dbf4768effa/0_0_1843_1037/1843.jpg?width=465&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)

2:11

'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video

There was a slight sense of double take about Amorim’s starting XI . OK. So, we’re going new energy, freshness, unforgiving demands on press and movement and structure. We’re going – it says here - with Casemiro, Christian Eriksen and Jonny Evans.

But it only took 82 seconds for everything to be all right, with a goal that came entirely from the Amorim rejig. Amad Diallo at right wing-back? Yep. We can do that too. Here he took the ball close to halfway and went straight into a full, ravenous, high rev sprint. The low cross with his newly empowered right foot was perfectly measured. Marcus Rashford just had to walk the ball into the net.

[skip past newsletter promotion](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/manchester-uniteds-joyless-incoherence-will-destroy-any-illusions#EmailSignup-skip-link-13)after newsletter promotion

[![Image 9: Ruben Amorim watches his first game from the touchline.](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/7ffa204443a161984538ddaf05fa37760035627c/0_200_6000_3600/master/6000.jpg?width=460&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=7fa0df662a7130025ff043a885b75d40) Amorim’s Manchester United pegged back by Ipswich after rapid start Read more](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)

Amorim’s reaction was perfect, in that there was no reaction, just a swivel back towards the bench, a flicker perhaps in the eyes. Rashford seemed out of sorts in those early moments. That is, he seemed hungry, energised and furiously mobile. He sprinted after lost passes, fouled and harried.

And for a while, as United had their best spell, there was a chance to linger on that vital quality, the Amorim touchline energy. There was an aura from the start, striding out in heavy-tog quilted coat, white trainers, skinny tailored slacks, off-the-peg Euro football royalty uniform. The package is good.

Jawline, hair, the controlled energy in his movements.

The United away support, which is always noisy, got to roll around and bounce and sing about the 12 Cantonas of Christmas. It didn’t last. Ipswich pressed back with real purpose, a process that is always easier when you find no resistance, a gap, a space to press into.

United’s midfield structure was odd, porous, leaving pathways that Ipswich began to trace, moving in neat triangles between the static parts. The equaliser was always coming, and it was fitting Omari Hutchison should score it after a sublime, high-craft first half.

Either side André Onana produced not one but two astonishing point-blank saves from Liam Delap. Delap is a wonderful spectacle in the flesh, a huge, thick barrelling figure, charging about as though he’s barely in control of his own gravity, a man always chasing a round of cheese down a Gloucestershire hillside. He really should have decided this game.

Amorim didn’t sit down through all of this. He didn’t scream and shout and point. Instead he paced, hands bunched in his pockets, in an ever shrinking arc from left to right. Somebody needs to take a cleaver to this thing. Amorim may have a kind of Left Bank soulfulness about him, soft deep brown eyes, the perfectly cropped bristles. But he is also clear-eyed and ruthless. And yes, he really is going to need all of that.

**Subscribe to Soccer with Jonathan Wilson, a weekly newsletter from one of the world’s top soccer journalists.**

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Jonathan Wilson

Columnist

'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video
===================================================================================

[Ruben Amorim](https://www.theguardian.com/football/ruben-amorim) said Manchester United are going 'to suffer for a long period' after his managerial debut at the club ended in a 1-1 Premier League draw at Ipswich. He added: 'We start now, we risk a little bit, we suffer a little bit and in the next year we will be better at this point so we have to risk it a little bit. They are thinking too much because we are changing too much with two training \[sessions\] now without space to improve in training'.

*   [**Amorim’s Manchester United pegged back by Ipswich after rapid start**](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)

**Subscribe to Soccer with Jonathan Wilson, a weekly newsletter from one of the world’s top soccer journalists.**

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Jonathan Wilson

Columnist

'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video
===================================================================================

[Ruben Amorim](https://www.theguardian.com/football/ruben-amorim) said Manchester United are going 'to suffer for a long period' after his managerial debut at the club ended in a 1-1 Premier League draw at Ipswich. He added: 'We start now, we risk a little bit, we suffer a little bit and in the next year we will be better at this point so we have to risk it a little bit. They are thinking too much because we are changing too much with two training \[sessions\] now without space to improve in training'.

*   [**Amorim’s Manchester United pegged back by Ipswich after rapid start**](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)

'We will suffer for a long period': Ruben Amorim on Manchester United debut – video
===================================================================================

[Ruben Amorim](https://www.theguardian.com/football/ruben-amorim) said Manchester United are going 'to suffer for a long period' after his managerial debut at the club ended in a 1-1 Premier League draw at Ipswich. He added: 'We start now, we risk a little bit, we suffer a little bit and in the next year we will be better at this point so we have to risk it a little bit. They are thinking too much because we are changing too much with two training \[sessions\] now without space to improve in training'.

*   [**Amorim’s Manchester United pegged back by Ipswich after rapid start**](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/24/ipswich-manchester-united-premier-league-match-report)
    

**Subscribe to Soccer with Jonathan Wilson, a weekly newsletter from one of the world’s top soccer journalists.**

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Jonathan Wilson

Columnist

**_Manchester United are keen on Wolves wing-back Rayan Ait-Nouri, but face competition for Chelsea striker Christopher Nkunku, Newcastle may need to sell before pursuing move for Bournemouth's Antoine Semenyo._**

New **Manchester United** manager Ruben Amorim is keen on **Wolves'** 23-year-old Algeria wing-back, Rayan Ait-Nouri. [(Sun), external](https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/31913903/man-utd-amorim-transfer-wolves-ait-nouri/)

The Red Devils are also interested in **Chelsea's** Christopher Nkunku but could face competition from **Borussia** **Dortmund** for the 27-year-old France forward. [(Teamtalk), external](https://www.teamtalk.com/news/man-utd-transfers-rival-dortmund-frustrated-chelsea-ace-perfect-ruben-amorim-signing-sources)

**Newcastle** are interested in **Bournemouth's** 24-year-old Ghana forward Antoine Semenyo but are unlikely to make a January move unless other players leave. [(Sky Sports), external](https://www.skysports.com/football/live-blog/11095/13025496/newcastle-transfer-news-rumours-and-gossip-live-updates-and-latest-on-deals-signings-loans-and-contracts?postid=8677197#liveblog-body)

**Fulham** and **Leicester** are eyeing a loan deal in January for **Brighton's** 20-year-old Republic of Ireland striker, Evan Ferguson. [(Football Insider), external](https://www.footballinsider247.com/exclusive-fulham-and-leicester-city-set-sights-on-evan-ferguson-deal/)

**Manchester City** are not looking to take advantage of a buy-back clause to bring English striker Liam Delap, 21, from **Ipswich**. [(Give Me Sport), external](https://www.givemesport.com/manchester-city-transfer-news-not-interested-triggering-delap-buyback-clause-etihad-stadium/)

**Everton** boss Sean Dyche has the full backing of current owner Farhad Moshiri and will be in charge for the foreseeable future. [(Sky Sports), external](https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11671/13260156/everton-reporter-notebook-sean-dyche-has-full-backing-of-current-ownership-despite-fan-discontent)

**Manchester United** have enquired about **Sporting's** 17-year-old Portugal U21s winger Geovany Quenda, who is valued at 60m euros (£50.1m). [(A Bola - in Portuguese), external](https://www.abola.pt/futebol/noticias/euro60-m-mais-bonus-para-o-man-united-levar-quenda-do-sporting-2024112422534275437)

The Red Devils are also targeting a number of strikers, with **PSG's** 25-year-old France international Randal Kolo Muani and **Eintracht Frankfurt's** Egypt forward Omar Marmoush, 25, on the club's radar. [(Sky Germany - in German), external](https://sport.sky.de/transfer/news/34132/13260554/marmoush-boniface-davies-transfer-themen-bei-manchester-united)

**United** are monitoring **Wolves'** 25-year-old Brazil forward Matheus Cunha, with **Tottenham** also showing interest. [(TBR Football), external](https://tbrfootball.com/what-wolves-have-told-gary-oneil-about-matheus-cunha-as-man-united-and-tottenham-circle-ahead-of-january/)

**AC Milan** are set to rival **Newcastle** for the signing of **Everton's** 27-year-old England striker Dominic Calvert-Lewin, while **Real Madrid** are considering a move for the Toffees' England defender Jarrad Branthwaite, 22. [(Teamtalk), external](https://www.teamtalk.com/news/everton-transfers-ac-milan-battle-newcastle-star-team-mate-concrete-real-madrid-target-sources)

**Manchester City** are confident Norway striker Erling Haaland, 24, will follow manager Pep Guardiola in signing a new contract with the club. [(Give Me Sport), external](https://www.givemesport.com/manchester-city-transfer-news-increasingly-confident-haaland-agree-deal-etihad-stadium/)

**Barcelona** are eyeing a 70m euro (£58.4m) deal for **Sporting Lisbon's** 26-year-old Sweden striker, Viktor Gyokeres. [(Sport - in Spanish), external](https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/barca/formula-barca-fichar-gyoekeres-112041417)

**Brighton** are to take **Cork** **City's** 17-year-old Ireland Under-18s winger Matthew Murray on trial. [(Irish Mirror), external](https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/soccer/soccer-news/brighton-take-highly-rated-cork-34185391)

**Nottingham Forest** are confident they will agree a new contract with 28-year-old Nigeria full-back Ola Aina. [(Football Insider), external](https://www.footballinsider247.com/nottingham-forest-confident-of-agreeing-ola-aina-deal-sources/)

**PSG's** 29-year-old Slovakia defender **Milan Skriniar** is set to join Juventus in the January transfer window. [(Foot Mercato - in French), external](https://www.footmercato.net/a5501618204879572456-psg-milan-skriniar-a-donne-son-accord-a-la-juventus)

Tottenham may look to sign a goalkeeper in January after Italy's Guglielmo Vicario, 28, suffered a broken ankle that required surgery. [(Telegraph - subscription required), external](https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/11/25/tottenham-transfer-news-vicario-injury-keeper-january/)

BBC Sport journalist

Manchester United fans hope Ruben Amorim will be 'The Man' but he was hoping for more points than just 'One'.

2. **Alex Turk**  
Fan writer

Why did Manchester United not look as good as Sporting against Ipswich Town on Sunday? Can this Ruben Amorim fella walk the walk as well as he talks the talk? How is this 3-4-3 system going to click?  

Amorim understands that only wins will buy him time, but that has not deterred his repeated cries for patience.  

Amorim cannot be judged this early on.  

I loved his post-match quote about staying true to his plan, regardless of the squad at his disposal.  

While United lacked legs in defence and midfield - already a known issue.  

3. **BBC Radio 5 Live's Monday Night Club** debated Manchester United's draw with Ipswich in Ruben Amorim's first game in charge.

**On adapting to his formation**: "It was really hard for them... they tried hard. They have so much space to improve..."

Ruud van Nistelrooy could help Manchester United complete four transfers amid new job talk - Amie Wilson - Manchester Evening News

The latest Manchester United transfer news and opinion as the former striker is the bookmakers odds-on favourite for the vacant Leicester City job.

By

Amie Wilson

19:30, 26 NOV 2024 

There has been a lot of talk over the future of Ruud van Nistelrooy since his Manchester United exit just a couple of weeks ago.

The former striker returned to United in the summer as assistant to Erik ten Hag. The manager’s sacking in October led to van Nistelrooy taking interim charge of the club.

In his four games in charge, United won three and drew one. Two of those wins came against Leicester City - a 5-2 Carabao Cup victory and a 3-0 win in the Premier League.

The appointment of Ruben Amorim led to uncertainty over van Nistelrooy’s future, and it was announced on the new head coach’s first day at the club that he would be leaving. It now seems that van Nistelrooy is set for a quick return to coaching.

Following the sacking of Steve Cooper, the Dutchman is currently odds-on favourite to take over at Leicester. If it does happen, a reunion with United will be on the cards in March when they travel to the King Power Stadium.

Van Nistelrooy's relationship with United could potentially benefit both clubs, especially with the January transfer window not far away. With that in mind, here are four United players that the former coach could potentially sign with his new club.

**Harry Maguire**

The centre-back’s time at United looks to be coming to an end, so could a return to his former club be a possibility? Maguire joined United from Leicester in the summer of 2019 for a fee of £80 million after two successful seasons at the club, where he also established himself as an England regular.

The 31-year-old has just six months remaining on his contract at Old Trafford. So he can either be sold for a reduced fee in January, or move on for nothing in the summer.

Leicester do have Conor Coady and Jannik Vestergaard as the more experienced centre-back options, but could turn to Maguire if they want to add to their backline.

**Toby Collyer**

The 20-year-old has broken into the squad this season, making an appearance in the second half of the 3-0 defeat against Liverpool back in September. He has however, struggled for appearances since then and has not made the squad in the last seven Premier League games.

A loan move for more game time, and if that could come with a Premier League club like Leicester, then all the better. The Foxes do however have both of their loan slots taken up, it would mean that they would have to either send back or arrange a permanent deal for the two players currently on loan to do another temporary deal.

**Antony**

Antony has failed to live up to his price tag at United since making the move from Ajax in 2022. United paid an initial £82 million fee to bring him to Old Trafford.

It has however been rumoured that they could look to move the winger on in the upcoming transfer window. To do that, it will either have to be for a greatly reduced price, or on a loan deal.

If United could send him on loan to a fellow Premier League club and he refinds his form and confidence. His return would either help him start again at the club, or increase his asking price in the summer window.

**Ethan Wheatley**

Leicester are expected to be on the lookout for another forward in the January window, and that could be the case even more if van Nistelrooy is in charge. If they have a loan slot available, then one possibility could be young United striker Ethan Wheatley.

He has been named in the squad for the Europa League games against Fenerbahce and PAOK, as well as Premier League matches against Liverpool, Southampton, Brentford, West Ham and Chelsea.

The chance to work with van Nistelrooy again as well as getting more Premier League experience could be invaluable for the youngster as he looks to break into the United first team.

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

Elon Musk congratulated former Manchester United forward Cristiano Ronaldo after Al Nassr won their fourth consecutive AFC Champions League match.

Cristiano Ronaldo, 39, scored twice for the Saudi Pro League side as they beat Qatar Stars League side Al Gharafa away in Al Rayyan. Former Newcastle United and Stoke City striker Joselu, who spent last season on loan at Real Madrid, scored a consolation for the hosts after the brace and a goal from the one-time Chelsea winger Angelo Gabriel.

Ronaldo shared a photo of himself and the latter doing his _Siu_ celebration during the match on the social media platform Musk owns, X, formerly Twitter, afterwards. Eight minutes after posting, "Big win tonight!" Musk replied.

"Congrats!" the businessman wrote, to which Ronaldo eventually responded approaching 20 hours later: "@elonmusk … Glad your eyes have time for good “soccer”" He punctuated that response with a grinning face emoji and a flexed biceps emoji. The original post has over 68 million views, and Ronaldo has almost 114 million followers on the website, some 100 million less than Musk's 206 million.

The win comes three days after Al Nassr lost for the first time in the Saudi Pro League this season at home to Al Qadisiyah. Despite taking the lead through Ronaldo, the Mexico international Julian Quinones equalised before former Arsenal captain Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang scored what proved to be the winning goal.

Al Nassr has won just one of its last five domestic matches. They also drew with Al Hilal and Al Kholood and were knocked out of the King Cup of Champions by Al Taawoun.

However, they have now qualified for the Champions League knockout stages with three games to spare. They sit second in the West Region table - all three Saudi sides occupy the top three places.

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

'Adaptable' - Gary Neville names four Manchester United players who will be key for Ruben Amorim - Manchester Evening News

Gary Neville is confident certain players will thrive under new Man United head coach Ruben Amorim.

By George Smith Senior Football Writer

* 11:00, 26 NOV 2024

Gary Neville has picked the bones out of Ruben Amorim's first game in charge.

Gary Neville believes Luke Shaw is a "certainty" to become a key figure under Ruben Amorim, insisting those who are "adaptable" will blossom under the new Manchester United head coach.

The England international made his long-awaited comeback from injury in Sunday's 1-1 draw with Ipswich Town at Portman Road, stepping off the bench 11 minutes into the second half.

It marked his first appearance of any kind since England's 2-1 defeat to Spain in the European Championship final in July and his first in United colours since February.

He slotted into the left-sided centre-back berth after replacing Jonny Evans. United were light on centre-back options at Portman Road, missing Leny Yoro, Lisandro Martinez and Harry Maguire.

Amorim, as expected, deployed a 3-4-3 formation, meaning he will need to be able to rely on his centre-backs to fill those three spaces in defence. And for Neville, he believes Shaw and Yoro could be among the biggest winners of his appointment, likewise midfield duo Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo, neither of whom started on Sunday.

"Luke Shaw, if he can keep fit [will be a winner]," said Neville. "As I think that left centre-back needs to eventually be able to play out as a left-back, so he is well suited to do both. The same must be said of the right centre-back.

"We saw [Noussair] Mazraoui do it against Ipswich. I think Ugarte will be a winner, just because I think in midfield, not just because he's played for him before.

"I think it's how you fit in the likes of [Marcus] Rashford, [Alejandro] Garnacho, Bruno Fernandes. Because one thing you know with that system, you've got two wing-backs, you've got a back-three and you've got a two in front.

"It's then that three, which obviously the two that he likes to play sort of come inside a little bit. So, you're wondering about sort of Amad... Amad played obviously wide yesterday, but Garnacho, Rashford, [Rasmus] Hojlund, [Joshua] Zirkzee, Fernandes. That's the conundrum of those attacking positions where I can't quite see what's going to happen.

"I think Mainoo and Ugarte for me, playing midfield, I think they're absolute certs. I think Luke Shaw's a certainty to play. I think he would be anyway in a back four or a back three.

"I think ultimately you'll end up with Yoro as the right-centre-back, I think just because of that energy and that pace. So, I think the winners will be the ones who I think are adaptable."

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

Erik ten Hag's Manchester United legacy to Ruben Amorim speaks volumes - Manchester Evening News

Manchester United's new era under Ruben Amorim began with a 1-1 draw at Ipswich Town where the new 3-4-3 system was debuted.
By Jack Flintham, Sport Central Audience Writer

Manchester United have been told to write this season off after a historically poor start to the Premier League under Erik ten Hag.

The Dutchman was fired by Ineos on October 28 following a 2-1 defeat at West Ham United. After he left Old Trafford on the Monday, the Reds wasted little time finding his successor with Ruben Amorim appointed the following Friday.

Due to an agreement with Sporting Lisbon, Amorim did not begin work at Old Trafford until Monday, November 11 - the start of the final international break of the year. As such, his first match in charge of the club came on Sunday when United drew 1-1 at Ipswich Town despite taking the lead inside 90 seconds.

Of course, it will take longer than one match to implement a new style on this United team but former Arsenal winger Theo Walcott believes the Reds need to let this season go particularly with such a relentless run of games between now and the new year. He told Sky Sports' Monday Night Football: "That [implementing a new season] is the difficulty he is going to have at this part of the season. The November/December period before Christmas is for me always an interesting time where it is all about recovery for the players. I think at times now, the players are just going to have to get on with it and need to learn really quickly. They will do a lot of walkthrough, I would have thought, but they need to get in the habits, plant the seed which will be repetition, repetition just to adapt to the system. They will have to learn very quickly but I think as well, they need to just write off this season. It has been a long time [of pain] for Man United and they are going to have to accept that as they have got the man they want now. But, how long will they stay in this system particularly when they want to get results?"

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

Man Utd - Transfer news, results, fixtures, video and audio
===============

Manchester United
=================

Latest updates
--------------

1. **Henry Brownsey**  
BBC Sport journalist

Manchester United fans hope Ruben Amorim will be 'The Man' but he was hoping for more points than just 'One'.

2. **Alex Turk**  
Fan writer

Why did Manchester United not look as good as Sporting against Ipswich Town on Sunday? Can this Ruben Amorim fella walk the walk as well as he talks the talk? How is this 3-4-3 system going to click?  

Amorim understands that only wins will buy him time, but that has not deterred his repeated cries for patience.  

Amorim cannot be judged this early on.  

I loved his post-match quote about staying true to his plan, regardless of the squad at his disposal.  

While United lacked legs in defence and midfield - already a known issue.  

3. **BBC Radio 5 Live's Monday Night Club** debated Manchester United's draw with Ipswich in Ruben Amorim's first game in charge.  

Former Premier League midfielder Michael Brown described the performance as a "reality check" and Chris Sutton said Amorim will have realised the squad is "bang average" and that "there is a hell of a lot of work to do".  

4. **Ruben Amorim** speaking to BBC Sport:  
"Not a good result... we started very well but should have had more of the ball. But we are learning."  

**On adapting to his formation**: "It was really hard for them... they tried hard. They have so much space to improve..."  

Published on: 2024-11-27

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

Viktor Gyokeres has finally 'made up his mind' on the club he wants to join in blockbuster transfer - Transfer News - SPORTbible

**Sporting Clube de Portugal star man Viktor Gyokeres has reportedly decided his next club.**

Gyokeres is one of the most sought-after players in Europe after yet another fine start to the season.

So far, the Swedish international has scored 24 goals in 19 appearances across all competitions. The 26-year-old also has four assists to his name.

As a result of his spectacular form, Gyokeres has been linked with a host of different clubs around the continent, including the likes of Manchester United, Liverpool, Arsenal, Chelsea, Paris Saint Germain and Barcelona.

However, since Ruben Amorim left Sporting for Old Trafford, reports linking Gyokeres with a move to United have picked up.

It has now been claimed that the striker has made up his mind on which club he wants to join in the future.

As reported by The Sun, Gyokeres has his eyes set on a move to Old Trafford, in what would be a reunion with former boss Amorim.

The report stated: "SunSport understands Sporting Lisbon striker Gyokeres has his heart set on a move to the Premier League and a reunion with ex-boss Ruben Amorim at Manchester United."

Before joining United, Amorim was asked about potentially reuniting with Gyokeres at Old Trafford.

The Portuguese said: "No, no, no. I cannot be funny with that in this moment. It was tough for me to leave, if I start joking about that with Gyokeres, I’ll have problems. This is my city, this is my country, I will respect.

"Viktor has to stay until the end of the season and then his life is going, maybe, somewhere else."

When asked about about Amorim, Gyokeres himself said: "We will miss him a lot, of course.

"We achieved a lot together and we will miss him and the other members of the staff, but they are leaving and we have to move on and face the next challenge we have."

Gyokeres is set to start for Sporting as they resume their UEFA Champions League campaign against Arsenal at the Estadio Jose Alvalade on Tuesday night.

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

Ruud van Nistelrooy could help Manchester United complete four transfers amid new job talk - Amie Wilson - Manchester Evening News

The latest Manchester United transfer news and opinion as the former striker is the bookmakers odds-on favourite for the vacant Leicester City job.

By

Amie Wilson

19:30, 26 NOV 2024 

There has been a lot of talk over the future of Ruud van Nistelrooy since his Manchester United exit just a couple of weeks ago.

The former striker returned to United in the summer as assistant to Erik ten Hag. The manager’s sacking in October led to van Nistelrooy taking interim charge of the club.

In his four games in charge, United won three and drew one. Two of those wins came against Leicester City - a 5-2 Carabao Cup victory and a 3-0 win in the Premier League.

The appointment of Ruben Amorim led to uncertainty over van Nistelrooy’s future, and it was announced on the new head coach’s first day at the club that he would be leaving. It now seems that van Nistelrooy is set for a quick return to coaching.

Following the sacking of Steve Cooper, the Dutchman is currently odds-on favourite to take over at Leicester. If it does happen, a reunion with United will be on the cards in March when they travel to the King Power Stadium.

Van Nistelrooy's relationship with United could potentially benefit both clubs, especially with the January transfer window not far away. With that in mind, here are four United players that the former coach could potentially sign with his new club.

**Harry Maguire**

The centre-back’s time at United looks to be coming to an end, so could a return to his former club be a possibility? Maguire joined United from Leicester in the summer of 2019 for a fee of £80 million after two successful seasons at the club, where he also established himself as an England regular.

The 31-year-old has just six months remaining on his contract at Old Trafford. So he can either be sold for a reduced fee in January, or move on for nothing in the summer.

Leicester do have Conor Coady and Jannik Vestergaard as the more experienced centre-back options, but could turn to Maguire if they want to add to their backline.

**Toby Collyer**

The 20-year-old has broken into the squad this season, making an appearance in the second half of the 3-0 defeat against Liverpool back in September. He has however, struggled for appearances since then and has not made the squad in the last seven Premier League games.

A loan move for more game time, and if that could come with a Premier League club like Leicester, then all the better. The Foxes do however have both of their loan slots taken up, it would mean that they would have to either send back or arrange a permanent deal for the two players currently on loan to do another temporary deal.

**Antony**

Antony has failed to live up to his price tag at United since making the move from Ajax in 2022. United paid an initial £82 million fee to bring him to Old Trafford.

It has however been rumoured that they could look to move the winger on in the upcoming transfer window. To do that, it will either have to be for a greatly reduced price, or on a loan deal.

If United could send him on loan to a fellow Premier League club and he refinds his form and confidence. His return would either help him start again at the club, or increase his asking price in the summer window.

**Ethan Wheatley**

Leicester are expected to be on the lookout for another forward in the January window, and that could be the case even more if van Nistelrooy is in charge. If they have a loan slot available, then one possibility could be young United striker Ethan Wheatley.

He has been named in the squad for the Europa League games against Fenerbahce and PAOK, as well as Premier League matches against Liverpool, Southampton, Brentford, West Ham and Chelsea.

The chance to work with van Nistelrooy again as well as getting more Premier League experience could be invaluable for the youngster as he looks to break into the United first team.

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

**Liverpool defender Andrew Robertson has broken Liverpool's silence after star player Mohamed Salah made a shock confession about his contract negotiations with the club.**

After their side came back back to [secure a hard-fought win over Southampton at St Mary's Stadium](https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/liverpool/liverpool-southampton-arne-slot-336586-20241124), [Liverpool](https://www.sportbible.com/liverpool) fans were shocked as [Salah](https://www.sportbible.com/mohamed-salah) aimed a dig at the club over his current contract extension negotiations.

The Egyptian, who netted a brace in the match, revealed that [he is yet to receive an offer from to extend his stay at the club](https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/liverpool/mo-salah-contract-negotiations-207279-20241125) ahead of his current deal expiring in the summer.

And now, teammate [Robertson](https://www.sportbible.com/andy-robertson) has become the first player at the club to address the comments, and he has made his stance on the situation clear.

Speaking ahead of Liverpool's [Champions League](https://www.sportbible.com/champions-league) clash with [Real Madrid](https://www.sportbible.com/real-madrid), Robertson said: "For us as players it's nothing we can get involved in. 

"All I can say is: look at Mo today, yesterday, he's the ultimate professional. It goes for all three of them, Virgil and Trent too, they are so focused on the next game and being leaders."

Liverpool manager [Arne Slot](https://www.sportbible.com/arne-slot) also spoke out about the incident, assuring fans that nobody at the club is concerned or distracted by it, certainly not Salah himself.

He said: "I don't think Mo is distracted at all. He just keeps on scoring. He is fully focused. The media and fans talk about it but at the AXA I didn't see anyone talking about it."

The Scotsman is the first current Liverpool player to speak about Salah's comments, after former player [Jamie Carragher spoke out against the winger on Monday.](https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/champions-league/liverpool-mo-salah-contract-jamie-carragher-475131-20241125) 

“I must say, I am very disappointed with Mo Salah,” Carragher said on [Sky Sports’ MNF.](https://x.com/SkySportsPL/status/1861122528883691772)

“\[With\] that interview yesterday…Liverpool have got Real Madrid midweek and Manchester City at the weekend – that’s the story for Liverpool right now.

“And Mo Salah, we’re all quite aware…that in the seven years he has been at the football club, he’s stopped in the mixed zone twice, which is his right, which is absolutely fine. 

“But he decided to stop for the third time away at Southampton on the back of winning Liverpool the game.”

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

# START OF ARTICLE TEXT

'Adaptable' - Gary Neville names four Manchester United players who will be key for Ruben Amorim - Manchester Evening News

Gary Neville is confident certain players will thrive under new Man United head coach Ruben Amorim.

By George Smith Senior Football Writer

* 11:00, 26 NOV 2024

Gary Neville has picked the bones out of Ruben Amorim's first game in charge.

Gary Neville believes Luke Shaw is a "certainty" to become a key figure under Ruben Amorim, insisting those who are "adaptable" will blossom under the new Manchester United head coach.

The England international made his long-awaited comeback from injury in Sunday's 1-1 draw with Ipswich Town at Portman Road, stepping off the bench 11 minutes into the second half.

It marked his first appearance of any kind since England's 2-1 defeat to Spain in the European Championship final in July and his first in United colours since February.

He slotted into the left-sided centre-back berth after replacing Jonny Evans. United were light on centre-back options at Portman Road, missing Leny Yoro, Lisandro Martinez and Harry Maguire.

Amorim, as expected, deployed a 3-4-3 formation, meaning he will need to be able to rely on his centre-backs to fill those three spaces in defence. And for Neville, he believes Shaw and Yoro could be among the biggest winners of his appointment, likewise midfield duo Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo, neither of whom started on Sunday.

"Luke Shaw, if he can keep fit [will be a winner]," said Neville. "As I think that left centre-back needs to eventually be able to play out as a left-back, so he is well suited to do both. The same must be said of the right centre-back.

"We saw [Noussair] Mazraoui do it against Ipswich. I think Ugarte will be a winner, just because I think in midfield, not just because he's played for him before.

"I think it's how you fit in the likes of [Marcus] Rashford, [Alejandro] Garnacho, Bruno Fernandes. Because one thing you know with that system, you've got two wing-backs, you've got a back-three and you've got a two in front.

"It's then that three, which obviously the two that he likes to play sort of come inside a little bit. So, you're wondering about sort of Amad... Amad played obviously wide yesterday, but Garnacho, Rashford, [Rasmus] Hojlund, [Joshua] Zirkzee, Fernandes. That's the conundrum of those attacking positions where I can't quite see what's going to happen.

"I think Mainoo and Ugarte for me, playing midfield, I think they're absolute certs. I think Luke Shaw's a certainty to play. I think he would be anyway in a back four or a back three.

"I think ultimately you'll end up with Yoro as the right-centre-back, I think just because of that energy and that pace. So, I think the winners will be the ones who I think are adaptable."

# END OF ARTICLE TEXT

article_metadata.article_headline: 'Adaptable' - Gary Neville names four Manchester United players who will be key for Ruben Amorim
